Posts.Title: im still around Ter faeriesong

Posts.Content: Jul 11, 2008 12:20PM faeriesong wrote: Amber - I'm so sorry.  And you are right - no one should be faced with decisions like this. It's such a personal decision that I don't feel I can offer an opinion one way or another.  You really must do what is right for you. It's so difficult.  The Doctor is right, he can't tell the future.  One thing that you said did jump out at me "My doctor would like me to go back on Taxol, because we stopped this treatment while it was still working..." So, hard though the Taxol was on you, it was working.  That's something to hold on to. I really don't envy you this decision and can completely understand why you don't feel ready to go back onto it.  If you put your hand in the fire and it burns, you don't put your hand in the fire again, right? That's one of the most cruel things about cancer.  You can feel better with it than you do when you're having the treatment! Sorry, I'm rambling.  I will pray for strength for you in making your choice. gentle hugs Mary xxx

Posts.Title: The Scanxiety is over mthomp2020 badboob67

Posts.Content: faeriesong wrote: Hi all, I've haven't posted on the boards for a while but have checked in often to keep an eye on everyone.  I am so shocked at how many sisters we have lost ~ I shed bitter tears for Shelli and Kelly...sigh I've been generally well up until recently.  About 5 months ago, I started getting pain in the top of my right arm/shoulder.  They thought I had a torn rotator cuff but the ultrasound showed that my rotator cuff is perfect!    The Orthopaedic guy that I saw, said that there's no point in Physio as I have full range of movement in it and ignored the fact that I have now have intense pins and needles in the ring and pinky finger and side of my right hand.  I now have to take Tramadol and Dicolflex to stop the pain so that I can sleep with it. Then about six weeks ago I started having trouble breathing.  I get puffed out really quickly.  Stupid things bring it on, like drinking too fast, talking too fast, bending over and getting too hot or too cold.  If I take it easy, it's still there but not so noticeable. I've seen several doctors, just finished my fourth round of antibiotics, been given a ventolin inhaler which did nothing and have just been given a steroid inhaler which doesn't seem to be doing much either. I had a chest X-ray a couple of weeks ago and three different doctors have given me three different results on the same X-ray.  "It's fine.", "It shows resolving infection." and yesterday I was told that it "...showed a partial collapse of my lower lobe." !?*  I wish they'd make their minds up! I don't have much confidence in the medical service here in the Outer Hebrides.  When I was in England, I had a Consultant Breast Surgeon, an Oncologist and a Breast Care Nurse.  Now I have a General Surgeon who I hardly ever see and a succession of GP's who don't seem to know what to do with me. The GP I saw yesterday is referring me to the Chest Specialist who comes over to our Island every so often so that could take ages.  The GP that I saw prior to that said she was going to refer me back to the Orthopaedic team but I've heard nothing. From your experience, does it sound like I need to push a lot harder or am I making something out of nothing?  I don't want to be a hypochondriac but I feel that I have to be my own advocate as no-one here seems to take my medical history seriously. Help! thanks in advance Mary xxx Never go to a doctor whose office plants have died ~ Erma Bombeck Dx 3/19/2004, IDC, 1cm, Stage I, Grade 3, 0/5 nodes, ER+ Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Apr 10, 2008 03:39AM faeriesong wrote: luckywife - when I was Nursing, we used to make a simple device to fit into the bed to support a dropped foot overnight. We used a 'drawsheet' for this but you can use an ordinary sheet.  Lay your flat sheet out flat.  Put a pillow at the top/middle.  Roll the pillow up in the sheet and then twist both ends of the sheet to form 'tails'.  What you're aiming for is a kind of bolster, with long tails that tuck in firmly underneath your mattress.  Imagine a wrapped candy - the pillow being the candy and the sheet being the wrapper but with extra long twists. You need to position it where your feet will be when you lie down to sleep, or if you're sitting up to read, start with it higher and then lower it for sleeping.  I hope that helps - if you don't get the description, let me know and I'll try and explain it better. big hugs Mary xxx

Something that you said really jumped out at me ;  "I don't want to suffer but if Christ can do it so can I." I want to be careful how I say this so that I don't get it 'wrong' and upset or offend anyone, but... ...what popped into my mind when I read that was 'God must really love Stephanie'.  And I don't mean that in a sarcastic way.  He so loved his only son and that poor guy suffered more than anyone.  What I don't get is why he has to keep on heaping the suffering on.  I guess that's where the faith really comes in.  We have to trust in his bigger plan. I really hope that you get where I'm coming from with this.  I haven't explained it well but it comes from the heart. Posts.Content: Mar 22, 2008 11:58AM faeriesong wrote: My toenails turned awful right after chemo.  My doc says it is because the chemo wipes out your immunities and so any fungal infections jump right in. I struggled on with them for ages and then last year, took a course of lamasil tablets.  Trouble is, they needed to do bloodtests frequently to monitor the lamasil effect on the liver and no one can ever get blood from me.  The last three attempts have been given up on - with me black and blue... I will try the Vicks Vaporub - I'd heard that before but never tried it. Sorry you guys have this issue too - but glad I'm not the only one with 'shameful' feet... hugs to all Mary xxx
